--- title: "babynames" format: html: toc: false section-divs: true include-after-body: - text: | engine: knitr filters: - webr webr: packages: - babynames autoload-packages: false cell-options: editor-font-scale: 0.85 fig-width: 6 fig-height: 3.7 out-width: "70%" --- ### Loading babynames {.no-hide} Before we begin, let's learn a little about our data. The `babynames` dataset comes in the {babynames} package. The package is pre-installed for you, just as {ggplot2} was pre-installed in the last tutorial. But unlike in the last tutorial, I have not pre-_loaded_ {babynames}, or any other package. What does this mean? In R, whenever you want to use a package that is not part of base R, you need to load the package with the command `library()`. Until you load a package, R will not be able to find the datasets and functions contained in the package. For example, if we asked R to display the `babynames` dataset, which comes in the {babynames} package, right now, we'd get the message below. R cannot find the dataset because we haven't loaded the {babynames} package. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} babynames ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'babynames' not found ``` ::: ::: To load the {babynames} package, you would run the command `library(babynames)`. After you load a package, R will be able to find its contents _until you close R_. The next time you open R, you will need to reload the package if you wish to use it again. This might sound like an inconvenience, but choosing which packages to load keeps your R experience simple and orderly. In the chunk below, load {babynames} (the package) and then open the help page for `babynames` (the dataset). Be sure to read the help page before going on. ::: {.panel-tabset} ## {{< fa code >}} Interactive editor ```{webr-r} ``` ## {{< fa circle-check >}} Solution ```r library(babynames) ?babynames ``` ::: ### The data Now that you know a little about the dataset, let's examine its contents. If you were to run `babynames` at your R console, you would get output that looks like this: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} babynames #> 187 1880 F Christina 65 6.659495e-04 #> 188 1880 F Lelia 65 6.659495e-04 #> 189 1880 F Nelle 65 6.659495e-04 #> 190 1880 F Sue 65 6.659495e-04 #> 191 1880 F Johanna 64 6.557041e-04 #> 192 1880 F Lilly 64 6.557041e-04 #> 193 1880 F Lucinda 63 6.454587e-04 #> 194 1880 F Minerva 63 6.454587e-04 #> 195 1880 F Lettie 62 6.352134e-04 #> 196 1880 F Roxie 62 6.352134e-04 #> 197 1880 F Cynthia 61 6.249680e-04 #> 198 1880 F Helena 60 6.147226e-04 #> 199 1880 F Hilda 60 6.147226e-04 #> 200 1880 F Hulda 60 6.147226e-04 #> [ reached getOption("max.print") -- omitted 1825233 rows ] ``` ::: Yikes. What is happening? ### Displaying large data `babynames` is a large data frame, and R is not well equipped to display the contents of large data frames. R shows as many rows as possible before your memory buffer is overwhelmed. At that point, R stops, leaving you to look at an arbitrary section of your data. You can avoid this behavior by transforming your data frame to a _tibble_. ## ::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
Next topic
:::
